results.title: Peep-peep-peep
results.brief_description: Puppet animated film about the Wombles who live under Wimbledon Common in London. In this episode the Wombles discover a crude version of the telephone by using tins and string. Based on the children’s book series The Wombles by Elizabeth Beresford. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

holdings.name: 16mm film; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: Raga Doll
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: This film features flashing lights that may potentially trigger seizures for people with photosensitive epilepsy.

The Frank Eidlitz Collection contains the 16mm and 35mm film work of graphic designer and visual artist Frank Eidlitz (1923–1997), predominantly made during a Winston Churchill Fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge in 1966. The collection contains Eidlitz’s experiments with light, movement and technology in film.

This short film, conceived by Frank Eidlitz and photographed by Maurice Amar, is titled ‘Raga Doll’ and explores experiments with light and movement. Its frenetic pace features fragmented footage of a woman dancing, overlaid with flashing lights and shapes. The accompanying soundtrack is frantic and wild, featuring fast-paced drums and vocal screams.

This film was screened at UBU Films’ ‘Experimental and Underground Movies’ in the Union Theatre, Sydney and at Strines Gallery, Melbourne in 1967, upon Eidlitz’s return to Australia from the US.

results.title: Calder
results.brief_description:
The Frank Eidlitz Collection contains the 16mm and 35mm film work of graphic designer and visual artist Frank Eidlitz (1923–1997), predominantly made during a Winston Churchill Fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge in 1966. The collection contains Eidlitz’s experiments with light, movement and technology in film.

This film shows the 1966 construction of Alexander Calder’s ‘La Grande Voile’ (The Big Sail), a monumental sculpture installed in McDermott Court at MIT in Cambridge.

Trained as a mechanical engineer, and born into a renowned family of artists, Calder began making kinetic artworks in the 1930s. Known as ‘mobiles’ the sculptures had moveable parts, were light and delicate in form, and often included a mechanical motor. By the late 1950s, Calder had begun making ‘stabiles’, which retained the sense of lightness and dynamism of his smaller works, but were formed on a monumental scale and stable on the ground. ‘La Grande Voile’ is emblematic of this period of his work.

‘La Grande Voile’ was a gift to MIT by Eugene and Margaret McDermott, who were arts patrons and benefactors to the institute. The sculpture was fabricated in France and shipped to MIT in parts; made up of five panels bolted together, the sculpture is 40 feet tall and comprised of 33 tons of painted steel.

The film features Calder overseeing the installation of ‘La Grande Voile’ in the courtyard. Footage of the artist wearing a hard hat is overlaid with footage of workers piecing the sculpture together. The film emphasises the interplay between the curved lines and angles of the steel sheets, and the balance between the monolithic weight and its delicate legs.

The film is accompanied by a recording of Bing Crosby’s ‘Dinah’, which is then spliced together with ‘Little Sir Echo’.

results.title: Basic music industry skills
results.brief_description: Basic Music Industry Skills is an accredited Certificate Level Course suitable for use across the Years 9 to 12 curriculum. This video series is divided into modules focusing on different aspects of the music industry. Geared specifically to a teenage audience, it is nevertheless both informative and entertaining.

results.title: History & styles of rock music in Australia
results.creator_credit: Euan Mitchell, Sylvie Leber, John Foss, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Serious Business
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Introduction to the Music Industry. Module 4.1. A fascinating look at the development of Australian rock music from its humble beginnings during Johnny O’Keefe’s “Wild One” days in the mid 1950’s, the struggles to gain recognition at home and overseas in the ‘60’s and ‘70’s to the international success of Australian acts in the ‘80’s and the diversity of styles in the ‘90’s. Through personal accounts, photographs and music video clips we examine, decade by decade, the music styles, fashions, changing technology and trends in Australian rock music including legendary performers such as The Easybeats, Russell Morris, AC/DC, Skyhooks, Cold Chisel and Midnight Oil.
results.title_for_label: History & styles of rock music in Australia
results.creator_credit_for_label: Euan Mitchell, Sylvie Leber, John Foss, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Serious Business

results.title: Songlines: contemporary aboriginal music
results.creator_credit: John Foss, Richard Frankland, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Introduction to the Music Industry. Module 4.6. Contemporary Australian Aboriginal music has become an international presence in recent years. This program profiles artists who have taken their brand of indigenous music to the world: Yothu Yindi, Archie Roach and Tiddas. Traditional elements are incorporated into contemporary styles. This is not simply a matter of throwing in the odd didjeridu and clap stick, but rather the traditional cultural role of Aboriginal music as an educational medium is maintained and extended to cover new, important issues and themes.

results.title: Making a music video on the cheap: from concept to completion
results.creator_credit: Greg Ferguson, AUSMUSIC and Conspiracy Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Module 21.2. This program demonstrates how a broadcast quality music video can be made for around $1,000. Shows the operation of a video camera and techniques such as white balance. Australian band Pelican Jed, take the viewer through a step by step analysis of their latest music video, highlighting the roles played by each member of the production team including interviews with the producer and director. The emphasis is to take the viewer from the concept stage to completion; where an idea becomes a reality.

results.title: Sisters are doin' it for themselves: women in the contemporary music industry
results.creator_credit: Greg Ferguson, Lindy Morrrison, AUSMUSIC and Conspiracy Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Module 4.5. Pursuing a career in the rock music industry is not easy for women and the path to success is often difficult. Lindy Morrison, an ex-band member of the groups The Go-Betweens and Cleopatra Wong, interviews women who have worked in artistic and non-artistic roles in the industry. In terms of gender balance, radio airplay, income and participant numbers, there is still room for improvement. Key female industy figures featured include Kylie Minogue, Wendy Matthews and Tina Arena, along with ‘pioneer’ artists such as Judy Stone, Laurel Lee and Little Pattie.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg Ferguson, Lindy Morrrison, AUSMUSIC and Conspiracy Films

results.title: Vacant possession
results.creator_credit: Margot Nash, John Winter, As If Productions, Australian Film Commission and Wintertime Films
results.brief_description: Following her mother’s death, Tessa returns to Australia and to her family home, a sun bleached weatherboard adjacent to Botany Bay. She confronts the collected debris of memory; the fears, the tears and the spectre of the father who forced her flee. Tessa’s home is close to that of an Aboriginal family she knew as a child. During her 20 year absence the nation has changed but not that house. In confronting her father, both the real and the remembered amidst the remains of the old home, the past and present collide in a maelstrom of unexpected ramifications. A brooding and atmospheric piece of cinema, Margot Nash’s first feature is an ambitious drama addressing hearth and place, rememberance and regret in a contemporary setting. Starring Pamela Rabe, John Stanton, Toni Scanlon, Linden Wilkinson, Rita Bruce and Olivia Patten.
